image.altText: A bald man in black tshirt and woman with long dark hair and grey jumper work in a drycleaning facility surrounded by machinery.

items.synopsis: Inflation has slowed down again, with consumer prices up 6 per cent over the year to June, below most economists' forecasts and reducing the chance of an RBA rate rise next week.

title.children: Inflation falls faster than expected. Has the Reserve Bank already increased interest rates too far?

image.altText: Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis side-by-side with his brain scan

items.synopsis: The effect of head knocks over Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis's decades-long sporting career isn’t immediately obvious. That is, until you see what’s happening to his brain.

title.children: From the age of 4, Gordi played contact sports. See how it has impacted his brain

image.altText: A woman in a two-tone denim jacket, stands at her kitchen bench.

items.synopsis: One in 25 Australians have lodged an insurance claim because of extreme weather since 2020, but should the remaining policyholders be responsible for sharing the cost of increased premiums?

title.children: Rachel's home insurance payments increased by $840 this year. She's just one Australian sharing the cost of more claims

image.altText: A woman with dark hair pulled into a bun smiles, standing in front of a floor to ceiling book shelf.

items.synopsis: Kamilaroi woman Louise Taylor becomes Australia's first female Indigenous Supreme Court judge. It is the second time she has made history, after she was appointed as the ACT's first Indigenous magistrate in 2018.

title.children: Louise Taylor has become Australia's first female Indigenous Supreme Court judge. It's not the first time she's made history

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Police say 31-year-old Mahmoud Abbas was shot by an unknown man outside a property in Greenacre this morning.

title.children: Sydney lawyer gunned down on same street where underworld figure was killed last year

image.altText: A group of volunteers surrounded by stranded pilot whales

items.synopsis: Authorities are urging the public to stay clear as they work to save the lives of the remaining 46 pilot whales stranded on Cheynes Beach.

title.children: 'Devastating': 51 whales dead on WA beach as difficult rescue effort continues

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Consumer inflation for the June quarter falls more than expected by economists, while the IMF warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation falls to 6 per cent as interest rate hikes dampen demand, ASX surges, IMF warns of economic challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business group, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the lower than expected price rises are welcome news for small businesses and consumers. It says annual inflation falling to a 12 month low eases pressure on the RBA when it meets next week. “Further cooling of inflation in the June quarter is the latest positive sign that the Reserve Bank’s interest rate rises are having their desired effect on price pressures,” says ACCI chief executive Andrew McKellar. “With falls now coming through, today’s data is encouraging for many small business owners who are now seeing the costs of doing business starting to ease." "Business reiterates its call for the Reserve Bank to hold rates at its August meeting, and take stock of the existing leverage of 12 rate increases since the beginning of the Reserve’s current tightening cycle.” Innes Willox, chief executive of the Australian Industry Group agrees the inflation data is positive. “The lower than expected annual rate of increase in inflation to the end of the March quarter, combined with the recent labour force data, should give some cause for hope that we are on track for a soft landing that retains as many of the recent gains in employment as possible," he says. And Mr Willox is warning that wage increases could add to inflation, concerns that have been echoed by the Reserve Bank, but which are dismissed by unions. “There are no guarantees that the landing will be soft and the path remains a narrow one." "It therefore remains critical that continued restraint is exercised by business, governments and employees in price setting and wage negotiations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business also calls for rates  pause

children.content: Business group, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the lower than expected price rises are welcome news for small businesses and consumers.
It says annual inflation falling to a 12 month low eases pressure on the RBA when it meets next week.
“Further cooling of inflation in the June quarter is the latest positive sign that the Reserve Bank’s interest rate rises are having their desired effect on price pressures,” says
ACCI chief executive Andrew McKellar.
“With falls now coming through, today’s data is encouraging for many small business owners who are now seeing the costs of doing business starting to ease."

"Business reiterates its call for the Reserve Bank to hold rates at its August meeting, and take stock of the existing leverage of 12 rate increases since the beginning of the Reserve’s current tightening cycle.”
Innes Willox, chief executive of the Australian Industry Group agrees the inflation data is positive.

“The lower than expected annual rate of increase in inflation to the end of the March quarter, combined with the recent labour force data, should give some cause for hope that we are on track for a soft landing that retains as many of the recent gains in employment as possible," he says.
And Mr Willox is warning that wage increases could add to inflation, concerns that have been echoed by the Reserve Bank, but which are dismissed by unions.
“There are no guarantees that the landing will be soft and the path remains a narrow one."
"It therefore remains critical that continued restraint is exercised by business, governments and employees in price setting and wage negotiations."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Council of Trade Unions wants the Reserve Bank to put interest rate increases on hold because of the drop in inflation. They note real wages are not keeping up with the cost of living and household budgets remain under pressure. Over the year, rents increased by 6.7 per cent, utilities rose nearly 14 per cent, and bread, milk and cheese prices have all soared. Here's ACTU assistant secretary Joseph Mitchell: “Today’s figures show that family budgets are still under unprecedented pressures with everyday items are eating more out of workers hard earned wages." "Corporate profits are still on the rise with data showing Australia had the third highest growth in profits  in the OECD between 2019 and 2023, indicating big business is price gouging workers through this  crisis." "The RBA should note this fall in inflation and not inflict any more pain on pockets of hard-working  Australians who are just trying to get on with everyday life, yet are being punished for a crisis they  played no part in."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACTU calls for rate hike pause

children.content: The Australian Council of Trade Unions wants the Reserve Bank to put interest rate increases on hold because of the drop in inflation.
They note real wages are not keeping up with the cost of living and household budgets remain under
pressure.
Over the year, rents increased by 6.7 per cent, utilities rose nearly 14 per cent, and bread, milk and cheese prices have all soared.
Here's ACTU assistant secretary Joseph Mitchell:
“Today’s figures show that family budgets are still under unprecedented pressures with everyday items are eating more out of workers hard earned wages."

"Corporate profits are still on the rise with data showing Australia had the third highest growth in profits  in the OECD between 2019 and 2023, indicating big business is price gouging workers through this  crisis."

"The RBA should note this fall in inflation and not inflict any more pain on pockets of hard-working  Australians who are just trying to get on with everyday life, yet are being punished for a crisis they  played no part in."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As Gareth, and the ABS, correctly point out, on an annual basis services inflation has picked up and is running at the highest level since the GST. But if you dive into the bureau's excel spreadsheets, you find the quarterly picture is quite different. Goods prices (+0.9%) actually increased by more in the June quarter compared to March than services prices (+0.8%). Moreover, the quarterly increase in services prices was the lowest in a year, falling dramatically from a peak of 2.1% in December — when travel providers jacked up prices for summer holidays. The main reason the annual reading is so high is that lower figures from the COVID period have now all dropped out of the annual data, which is dragged up by big services prices rises in the September (+1.6%), December (+2.1%) and March (+1.7%) quarters. The rise of 0.8% in the three months to June is less than half that seen in the previous quarter so, on that basis, services inflation is actually decelerating rather sharply. It must be noted, though, that these quarterly figures are NOT seasonally adjusted, and a quick look back through recent data hints that June is probably the weakest quarter for services price rises on average.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Quarterly data paints a slightly different picture on services inflation

children.content: As Gareth, and the ABS, correctly point out, on an annual basis services inflation has picked up and is running at the highest level since the GST.
But if you dive into the bureau's excel spreadsheets, you find the quarterly picture is quite different.
Goods prices (+0.9%) actually increased by more in the June quarter compared to March than services prices (+0.8%).
Moreover,
the quarterly increase in services prices was the lowest in a year
, falling dramatically from a peak of 2.1% in December — when travel providers jacked up prices for summer holidays.
The main reason the annual reading is so high is that lower figures from the COVID period have now all dropped out of the annual data, which is dragged up by
big services prices rises in the September (+1.6%), December (+2.1%) and March (+1.7%) quarters
The rise of 0.8% in the three months to June is less than half that seen in the previous quarter so, on that basis,
services inflation is actually
decelerating
rather sharply
It must be noted, though, that these quarterly figures are
NOT seasonally adjusted
, and a quick look back through recent data hints that
June is probably the weakest quarter for services price rises
on average.

image.altText: Photograph outside the Australian Tax Office headquarters

items.synopsis: Following an ABC Investigation, the Australian Tax Office admits criminals have fraudulently claimed more than $557 million from the Commonwealth using an identity loophole.

title.children: ATO admits identity loophole exposed by the ABC tops half a billion dollars

image.altText: A composite image of two women.

items.synopsis: A childcare boss's decision after learning two of her staff had left a three-year-old on a bus in central Queensland for several hours has been credited with saving the girl's life.

title.children: Tears as women who left child on daycare bus sentenced over 'nightmare situation'

image.altText: A man in a pink top smiling on a soccer pitch

title.children: Messi spurned $2.4b so he could play soccer for David Beckham in Miami. Here's why it's a savvy move

title.children: Matildas lose another attacking weapon in crucial World Cup clash with Nigeria

image.altText: Geoff and Rhonda doing a puzzle.

items.synopsis: Geoff is selectively mute and has a fragile X syndrome. When his mother engaged a disability service to take him to work, she didn't know it would use up almost all his NDIS funding.

title.children: Geoff was driven to work three days a week. He received a $700 invoice for it

image.altText: A collation of photos of football players.

title.children: Five quick hits — South Korean teen breaks World Cup record and controversial VAR denies New Zealand

image.altText: A close up of a man speaking while gesturing with his hand

image.altText: Timothy Shea stands outside the glass doors of Manhattan federal court.

image.altText: A man wearing a mask

items.synopsis: Damien Wanstall, who previously taught maths at Kellyville High School, was unaware the person he was engaging with online in 2020 was actually an undercover police officer and was arrested when he arranged to meet.

image.altText: A smiling young woman takes a selfie. A man, whose face is blurred, sits beside her.

image.altText: Meta logo in background in focus with blurry silhouette heads in foreground.

title.children: Free security app 'knows nearly everything' about users, court told as Facebook owners Meta fined $20m

image.altText: A red up arrow next to a percentage sign on top of an aerial view of dozens of houses.

items.synopsis: The level of mortgage arrears is creeping higher and the number of borrowers at risk of mortgage stress is at its highest level since 2008.

title.children: Nearly a million borrowers are 'extremely at risk' of mortgage stress, but very few are defaulting yet

image.altText: Composite image of young girl and police members and a search dog.

image.altText: Man poses in front of blue background wearing suit

image.altText: A jockey in red, white and blue silks rides a camel at high speed, with feet in stirrups, strop in hand and hair flying.

items.synopsis: She's best known as a travelling tent boxer with leg hairs so sharp "they could spear a rat" but Beaver Brophy, who has a CV that reads like a handful of darts thrown at a careers handbook, has added a bizarre new skill to her list of qualifications.

title.children: Travelling tent boxer Beaver Brophy becomes camel racing champion in Queensland outback

image.altText: A woman's hands type on a laptop keyboard.

items.synopsis: A Byron Bay woman's $1.8m legal nightmare highlights how hackers use username and password combinations leaked online to access other accounts, a scam on the rise due to recent major data breaches, experts warn.

title.children: Why you need to know about 'credential stuffing' — the latest way scammers are targeting your data

image.altText: a large aboriginal flag flying above a large group of people at a city march

items.synopsis: State and territory governments are not being held accountable for failing to meet Closing the Gap targets and in some cases are actively exacerbating disadvantage, a Productivity Commission report finds.

title.children: 'Another broken promise to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people': Report warns of continued disadvantage

image.altText: A graphic showing a confused person looking at different plastics.

items.synopsis: Do you know your PP from your HDPE, and your PVC from your soft plastics? Plastic recycling is a minefield, so here's how to tell what you're dealing with and which bin you should put it in.

title.children: Plastic not so fantastic: Do you know which numbers can't be recycled?

items.synopsis: Robert Hadden abused trusting and vulnerable patients for years and will serve the maximum sentence for the offences, which a judge described as "horrific".

title.children: Former US gynaecologist jailed for 20 years for molesting patients

image.altText: David Pass sits in the in Queensland Health's Forensic and Scientific Services lab, boxes of vapes stand nearby

items.synopsis: Impounded vapes are being tested for polonium-210, a radioisotope which naturally occurs in cigarette tobacco.

image.altText: A collation of photos of a football player.

title.children: How one moment of madness changed the trajectory of a Matildas star's football career
